Definition: Relational Database Management System: software that stores data in related tables, enforces constraints, and supports transactions (ACID), typically queried with SQL.
A data model that represents data as relations (tables) made of tuples (rows) and attributes (columns), with keys defining relationships.
A high-level business view of data: main entities and relationships, without technical details like data types or indexes.
A detailed, technology-agnostic design of entities, attributes, keys, and relationships (often normalized), ready to be implemented in a specific DB.
The implementation-specific design in a chosen DB: tables, columns, data types, indexes, constraints, partitioning, and storage details.
Entity-Relationship Diagram: a visual model of entities, attributes, and relationships including cardinality/optionality.
The process of designing how data is structured, related, and constrained to support a business domain (conceptual → logical → physical).
The correctness/validity of data, maintained through constraints, validation rules, and controlled updates.
Data agrees across the system (no contradictions) and remains coherent after transactions and updates.
A single piece of stored data in a record; often the value in a specific column for a row.
A property that describes an entity; typically implemented as a column in a table.
A classification that defines what values are allowed and how they are stored/processed (e.g., integer, text, date); used in both programming and databases.
Unnecessary duplication of the same fact in multiple places, which increases storage and can cause inconsistencies.
A unit of work that is all-or-nothing (commit/rollback) to keep data reliable; follows ACID principles.
How many instances of one entity can be associated with instances of another (1:1, 1:N, N:M).
A relationship where each row in A relates to at most one row in B, and each row in B relates to at most one row in A.
A relationship where one row in A can relate to many rows in B, while each row in B relates to one row in A.
An associative entity (junction table) used to represent a many-to-many relationship and/or store attributes about that relationship.
A rule enforced by the database to protect data quality (PRIMARY KEY, FOREIGN KEY, UNIQUE, NOT NULL, CHECK, etc.).
Column(s) that uniquely identify each row in a table; must be unique and not null.
A column that references a primary/unique key in another table to enforce referential integrity between rows.
A junction table that connects two tables in a many-to-many relationship (also called associative table).
The set of properties/columns that describe an entity or table.
A guarantee that foreign keys always reference existing rows (no 'orphan' references).
The table on the many-side of a relationship that holds the foreign key referencing a parent table.
The table on the one-side of a relationship that is referenced by foreign keys from child tables.
A real-world, meaningful identifier used as a key (e.g., email address), not generated by the system.
A system-generated identifier used as a key (e.g., SERIAL/IDENTITY/UUID) with no business meaning.
Any minimal set of column(s) that can uniquely identify a row; one candidate key is chosen as the primary key.
A candidate key that is not selected as the primary key but is still unique and can identify rows.
Design technique that structures tables to reduce redundancy and dependency problems, improving integrity and maintainability.
A design problem where you cannot insert a fact without also inserting unrelated data, due to poor table structure.
A design problem where the same fact must be updated in multiple rows/places, risking inconsistent values.
A design problem where deleting a row unintentionally removes other important facts because data was bundled together.
A set of rules (1NF, 2NF, 3NF, BCNF, etc.) that describe increasing levels of normalization and reduced redundancy.
BCNF: a stronger form of 3NF where every determinant is a candidate key, preventing certain redundancy anomalies.
When a non-key attribute depends on another non-key attribute (indirectly on the key), violating 3NF.
A relationship where one set of attributes determines another (if A is known, B is uniquely determined).
A relationship that involves three entities at the same time (cannot be accurately modeled as only pairwise relationships).
A primary key made of two or more columns (together uniquely identify rows).
A compact way to write a relational schema, e.g., R(A, B, C), with annotations for keys and constraints.
Entity constraints: rules that apply within a single table/entity (e.g., primary key uniqueness, not null, domain/check constraints).
Create, Read, Update, Delete: the four basic operations performed on stored data.
A request for data (or a change) expressed in SQL; commonly refers to SELECT statements that return a result set.
A complete instruction executed by a system (e.g., Python interpreter or SQL database), such as an assignment, a function definition, or a SQL command.
Data Definition Language: SQL for defining structures (CREATE, ALTER, DROP).
Data Manipulation Language: SQL for changing data (INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE).
A script/operation that can be run multiple times and still produces the same end state (safe re-runs).
A relational structure that stores rows (records) with the same columns; also called a relation.
A namespace and/or collection of database objects (tables, views, functions); also refers to the defined structure of data.
A single record/tuple in a table (one item of data across all columns).
A synonym for row: one complete set of column values in a table.
A named field in a table that stores one attribute type (e.g., email, created_at).
An organized collection of data and database objects (tables, indexes, views) managed by a DBMS.
Persistence: data is stored durably (on disk) and remains after the program/process ends.
Data Query Language: SQL used to query data, mainly SELECT.
A database that follows the relational model (tables + keys + constraints) and is queried with SQL.
Database client meta-commands (not SQL) such as psql backslash commands (e.g., \dt, \d, \x).
Command-Line Interface: interacting with a tool by typing commands in a terminal.
A common command-line shell used on Unix-like systems for running commands and scripts.
Automatically determining a value's type from context or data (e.g., importing CSV and guessing column types).
A part of a SQL statement with a specific role (SELECT, FROM, WHERE, GROUP BY, ORDER BY, etc.).
Giving a temporary name to a table or column (often using AS) to simplify references.
A SQL command executed by the database; same idea as a statement (SELECT/INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE/CREATE...).
A database stored on disk (durable), as opposed to an in-memory database that disappears when the process stops.
Write-Ahead Log file: a durability mechanism where changes are logged before being applied, enabling crash recovery.
Integrated Development Environment: an editor with tools like linting, debugging, and project management.
Comma-Separated Values: a plain-text tabular file format where each line is a row and fields are separated by commas.
A naming scope that keeps object names separate; in SQL often implemented as schemas (e.g., public.table).
Create, Read, Update, Delete: the four basic operations performed on stored data.
A request for data (or a change) expressed in SQL; commonly refers to SELECT statements that return a result set.
A complete instruction executed by a system (e.g., Python interpreter or SQL database), such as an assignment, a function definition, or a SQL command.
A namespace and/or collection of database objects (tables, views, functions); also refers to the defined structure of data.
Giving a temporary name to a table or column (often using AS) to simplify references.
Selecting which columns to return (the column list in SELECT), e.g., SELECT name, age FROM ...
Filtering which rows to return (typically via WHERE conditions).
A naming scope that keeps object names separate; in SQL often implemented as schemas (e.g., public.table).
The part of a query that specifies which columns/expressions are returned.
The part of a query that filters rows based on a condition.
A boolean expression (true/false) used for filtering or joining, e.g., WHERE age > 30.
A SQL operator for inclusive range checks, e.g., WHERE x BETWEEN 10 AND 20.
Functions that summarize many rows into one value (COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX).
Filtering rows by numeric/date ranges using operators like >, <, BETWEEN.
Filtering text based on patterns (LIKE/ILIKE) or regular expressions (regexp).
Filtering rows based on membership in a list, typically using IN (...).
Related to time-based data such as dates, timestamps, and time intervals.
A time duration (e.g., 7 days, 3 hours) used in date/time calculations.
Artificially generated (not from real-world source), e.g., synthetic test data or surrogate keys.
SQL keyword to provide literal row values, commonly used in INSERT or as a table-like construct.
A query nested inside another query (in SELECT, FROM, WHERE, etc.) whose result is used by the outer query.
A query formed by combining multiple SELECT results using set operations (UNION/INTERSECT/EXCEPT).
Operations that combine result sets as sets (UNION, UNION ALL, INTERSECT, EXCEPT).
Set operation that returns rows present in the first query but not in the second (set difference).
The table-shaped output returned by a query (rows + columns).
Set operation that combines results and removes duplicates (distinct).
Set operation that combines results and keeps duplicates (faster than UNION).
A symbol/keyword that performs an operation (e.g., =, <, +, AND, OR).
Set operation that returns only rows that appear in both result sets (set intersection).
A diagram showing overlaps between sets; often used to explain UNION/INTERSECT/EXCEPT visually.
Join that keeps all rows from the left table and matches from the right; non-matches on the right become NULL.
Join that returns only rows where the join condition matches in both tables.
Join that keeps all rows from the right table and matches from the left; non-matches on the left become NULL.
Pattern matching operator using % and _ wildcards; often case-sensitive depending on database/collation.
Case-insensitive version of LIKE in PostgreSQL.
Regular expression matching (database-specific), used to filter strings with regex patterns.
en extra kopia på någonting, används för säkerhet utifall någonting händer, t.ex en fil blir korrupt och ej läsbar. Har du en backup på originalet kan du läsa den istället utan problem.
kommandot git pull används för att hämta och ladda ner innehåll från ett repository och omedelbart uppdatera det lokala arkivet så att det matchar det innehållet.

git clone används för att skapa en lokal kopia av ett befintligt repo (remote repository), till exempel från GitHub, GitLab eller Bitbucket. Det laddar ner hela projektets historik, filer och alla grenar (branches) till din dator, vilket gör att du kan arbeta lokalt och senare synkronisera ändringar.
linux kommando som står för 'change directory'
linux kommando som står för 'list'
linux kommando som står för 'change directory bakåt'. Den flyttar dig bakåt en directory.
data type frågar om vad för TYP det är på datan. Heltal(integer), decimaler(float), text(string), Sant/Falskt(Boolean). Notera att det är stor skillnad på Data type och Data structure.
Data structures är ett sätt att organisera, lagra och hantera data för att kunna använda den effektivt. Exempel på datastruktur är, list [], tuple (), dictionary {}.
en variabel är som en behållare som du ger ett namn och ett värde, till exempel hw = 'Hello World'. Då kan du kalla på variabeln när som helst med hw istället för att skriva Hello World.
en tilldelning enkelt förklarat. Har du en variabel = 10 så innebär det att likhetstecknet tilldelar variabeln 10 (som är en int i detta exempel).
input är det som går in.
output är det som kommer ut.

innebär att en variabel av en viss datatyp konverteras till en annan. Till exempel: x = int(11.7), detta kommer bli 12 pga int är heltal och ej decimaler. https://www.w3schools.com/python/python_casting.asp
en bool är True eller False. If x = True, ... ... True är här en bool.
en string kännetecknas av 'text'
Leading whitespace that defines code blocks in Python (e.g., inside if/for/functions).
A recommended style or best practice (e.g., PEP 8) that improves readability but isn't required by the interpreter.
Language constructs that control execution flow, such as conditionals, loops, and exception handling.
A statement that chooses which block to run based on a condition (if/elif/else).
Starts a conditional block that runs only if its boolean condition is True.
An 'else if' branch: checked when previous if/elif conditions were False.
Fallback branch of a conditional that runs when no prior condition is True.
A loop that iterates over items in an iterable (list, range, dict, etc.).
A loop that repeats as long as its boolean condition remains True.
Immediately exits the nearest enclosing loop.
Skips the rest of the current loop iteration and continues with the next one.
An expression that evaluates to True or False (e.g., x > 0 and y < 5).
A control structure that repeats a block of code multiple times.
A loop inside another loop, used to iterate over combinations (e.g., rows and columns).
An if-statement inside another if-statement, used for multi-level decisions.
A piece of code that produces a value (e.g., 2 + 2, len(name), x > 3).
A complete instruction executed by a system (e.g., Python interpreter or SQL database), such as an assignment, a function definition, or a SQL command.
The order in which statements execute (including branches, loops, and exceptions).
A control flow where statements run top-to-bottom in the order they are written.
A mutable, ordered collection of items, written with square brackets: [1, 2, 3].
An immutable, ordered collection of items, written with parentheses: (1, 2, 3).
An unordered collection of unique items, written with braces: {1, 2, 3}.
A built-in that generates a sequence of integers, commonly used for looping (range(0, n)).
Accessing an element by position using square brackets, e.g., s[0].
Taking a subsequence using start:stop:step, e.g., s[1:4] or s[::-1].
A concise way to build collections (list/set/dict) from an iterable, e.g., [x*x for x in nums].
A function that combines iterables element-by-element into tuples, e.g., zip(names, ages).
A misspelling of enumerate: a function that yields (index, item) pairs when looping.
Assigning elements of an iterable to variables (a, b = pair) or expanding with * and ** in calls.
Checking whether a value exists in a container (e.g., x in items, key in dict).
A string method that returns a new string with occurrences of a substring replaced.
A pattern language (re module) used to search, match, or split text based on patterns.
Joining values together, e.g., 'a' + 'b' or list1 + list2.
A string method that splits text into a list using a delimiter, e.g., 'a,b'.split(',').
Accessing an element by position using square brackets, e.g., s[0].
Special sequences in strings starting with backslash, e.g., \n (newline), \t (tab), \\ (backslash).
A universal character set standard; Python's str type stores Unicode text.
An error event that interrupts normal execution; exceptions can be raised and handled.
A block where you place code that may raise an exception.
A block that catches and handles exceptions raised in the try block.
A block that runs whether an exception occurred or not, typically for cleanup.
A detailed error report showing the call stack and where an exception occurred.
A built-in function that opens a file and returns a file object for reading/writing.
A statement that uses a context manager to ensure resources are cleaned up automatically.
An object that manages setup/teardown for a block (implements __enter__ and __exit__).
A method that closes a resource (file/connection) and frees underlying system handles.
Keyword used to define a function.
Executing a function by writing its name followed by parentheses, optionally with arguments.
A value passed into a function call.
A statement that sends a value back from a function and stops its execution.
A named variable in a function definition that receives an argument when the function is called.
A function parameter with a default value used when no argument is provided.
Arguments passed by name (f(x=1)), making calls clearer and order-independent.
*args and **kwargs: parameters that accept a variable number of positional/keyword arguments.
Arguments matched to parameters by their position in the function call.
Small anonymous functions created with the lambda keyword, often used for simple callbacks.
The dictionary constructor; creates a mapping of keys to values (e.g., dict(a=1)).
Dictionary method to fetch a value by key with an optional default if the key is missing.
Dictionary method returning a view of (key, value) pairs, useful for looping.
Operator used for membership tests (x in list) and for iterating in loops (for x in items).
Keyword that deletes a variable name, a dictionary key, or a slice of a list.
Dictionary method that merges another mapping into the dict, overwriting existing keys.
Keyword used to define a class (a blueprint for creating objects).
An instance of a class; also the root base class in Python that most classes inherit from.
A concrete object created from a class (e.g., x = MyClass()).
Bundling data and behavior together and hiding internal details behind a clear interface.
A convention for internal attributes (leading underscore) indicating 'do not use directly' (not strictly enforced).
A managed attribute created with @property that lets you add logic to getting/setting a value.
Checking that data meets rules (types, ranges, required fields) before using or storing it.
Hiding implementation details and exposing only the essential interface users need.
Different types can be used through the same interface (duck typing), e.g., anything with __len__ works with len().
Multiple methods with the same name but different signatures; Python doesn't support it directly, often emulated with defaults/dispatch.
Defining a class based on another class to reuse/extend behavior (an 'is-a' relationship).
Building objects from other objects (a 'has-a' relationship), often preferred over deep inheritance.
The class that another class inherits from (superclass/parent).
Another name for base class: the class being inherited from.
Informal term for a superclass in an inheritance relationship.
Informal term for a subclass that inherits from a parent/superclass.
An automated test that checks a small unit of code (a function/method) in isolation.
A check that a condition is true; in tests it defines expected behavior.
A measure of how much code is executed by the test suite (not the same as correctness).
Test-Driven Development: write a failing test first, then implement code to make it pass, then refactor.
To assign means to set a value; in pandas, assign() creates new columns in a DataFrame (often without mutating the original).
A logical error is a bug where code runs without crashing but produces the wrong result.
Error handling is writing code that detects failures and responds safely (messages, retries, fallback, or clean exit).
Accessing an element by position using square brackets, e.g., s[0].
Taking a subsequence using start:stop:step, e.g., s[1:4] or s[::-1].
An iterable is an object you can loop over (it produces items one by one), like lists, strings, or generators.
To iterate over means to loop through each item in a collection, one at a time.
A list comprehension is a compact way to build a new list from an iterable in a single expression.
In Python, the collections module provides specialized container types like Counter, defaultdict, and deque.
A tuple is an immutable (unchangeable) ordered collection in Python, written with parentheses or commas.
__repr__ is a Python 'dunder' method that returns an unambiguous string representation of an object (useful for debugging).
Dunder methods are special Python methods with double underscores (e.g., __init__, __repr__) that customize object behavior.
Pythonic means written in a clear, idiomatic style that fits Python conventions.
Idiomatic code follows the common style and patterns of a language, making it easier to read and maintain.
Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY): a principle that encourages avoiding duplicated code by reusing functions, modules, or shared logic.
Spaghetti code is tangled, hard-to-follow code with poor structure and many hidden dependencies.
Arguments passed by name (f(x=1)), making calls clearer and order-independent.
Arguments matched to parameters by their position in the function call.
In Python, *args collects extra positional arguments into a tuple inside a function.
In Python, **kwargs collects extra keyword arguments into a dictionary inside a function.
Unpacking means assigning elements from a list/tuple into multiple variables (e.g., a, b = [1, 2]).
A statement that sends a value back from a function and stops its execution.
A ternary operator is a one-line conditional expression: x if condition else y.
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a text format for structured data, commonly used in APIs.
A DataFrame is a 2D table-like data structure in pandas with labeled rows and columns.
A Series is a 1D labeled array in pandas (similar to a single column with an index).
pandas concat() combines multiple Series/DataFrames by stacking rows or columns.
pandas apply() runs a function on each row or column (or element) to transform data.
Comma-Separated Values: a plain-text tabular file format where each line is a row and fields are separated by commas.
pandas isnull()/isna() checks for missing values (NaN/None) and returns a boolean mask.
Masking in pandas means filtering rows using boolean conditions (e.g., df[df['col'] > 0]).
pandas transpose (df.T) swaps rows and columns in a DataFrame.
pandas value_counts() counts unique values in a Series and returns frequencies.
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a text format for structured data, commonly used in APIs.
Tabular data is data organized in rows and columns (like a spreadsheet or database table).
Zero-based indexing means sequences start at index 0 (first element is at position 0).
The host system is the machine/OS that runs containers or virtual environments.
Virtualization is running isolated environments on a host machine (VMs or containers) to separate workloads.
To spin up means to start and make a service/resource ready (e.g., start containers or servers).
To dockerize an app means packaging it into a Docker image so it can run consistently anywhere.
docker build creates a Docker image from a Dockerfile.
docker run creates and starts a new container from an image.
Docker image layers are cached filesystem snapshots created by each build step, enabling faster rebuilds.
A container is a lightweight isolated runtime for an application and its dependencies, sharing the host OS kernel.
A Docker image is a packaged template of an application and its dependencies used to create containers.
docker compose up -d starts services in the background (detached).
docker compose up --build starts services and rebuilds images before running them.
docker compose down stops and removes containers (and optionally networks/volumes).
docker inspect shows detailed JSON information about a Docker object (container, image, network, etc.).
docker ps lists running containers.
docker volume ls lists Docker volumes used for persistent storage.
docker container ls -a lists all containers, including stopped ones.
docker image ls -a lists all images, including intermediate ones.
docker image prune removes unused images to free disk space.
docker container prune removes stopped containers to free disk space.
A tag is a label used to identify a version or variant (e.g., a Git tag or a Docker image tag).
docker rm removes one or more containers (usually stopped containers).
Apache Kafka is a distributed event-streaming platform for publishing, storing, and consuming streams of messages.
An event is something that happens in a system and can trigger processing (e.g., a message arrival or a user action).
A message is a unit of data sent between systems (often via a queue or topic).
In messaging/pub-sub, a producer publishes messages to a topic or queue.
In messaging/pub-sub, a consumer is a process that reads messages from a queue or topic.
A topic is a named stream/channel of messages in pub/sub systems like Kafka.
To publish means to send data/messages so others can consume them (often to a topic/queue).
To subscribe means to register interest in a topic/stream so you receive matching messages.
A sink is the destination where data ends up (database, file, API, data warehouse).
Publish-subscribe (pub/sub) is a messaging pattern where producers publish to topics and subscribers receive matching messages.
A source system is where data originates (an API, app database, logs, sensors, etc.).
A partition is a slice of data used for scaling and parallelism (e.g., Kafka topic partitions or partitioned files).
Serialization converts an in-memory object into a storable/transmittable format (like JSON or bytes).
Deserialization converts stored/transmitted data (like JSON) back into an in-memory object (like dicts/classes).
In a pull model, consumers request data when they are ready (e.g., polling).
In a push model, producers send data to consumers as soon as it is available (event-driven).
A client is a program that requests data or services from a server (e.g., a browser calling an API).
In a pub/sub system, to advertise is to announce that a producer or service will publish certain messages or topics.
Port mapping publishes a container port to the host so services are reachable (e.g., host 8000 → container 8000).
Detached mode (Docker -d) runs a container in the background instead of blocking your terminal.
docker exec -it runs a command inside a running container with an interactive terminal.
In Matplotlib, an Artist is any drawable element on a figure (lines, text, patches, axes, etc.).
Containers are isolated application runtimes; you can run many containers from the same image.
In Matplotlib, spines are the border lines of an axes (top/bottom/left/right) that frame the plot.
Axes (plural) is the plotting area in Matplotlib that contains the data, ticks, labels, and most chart elements.
A figure is the overall canvas/container for one or more plots (e.g., a Matplotlib Figure).
A subplot is one chart within a grid of multiple charts in a single figure.
In Matplotlib, a Patch is a 2D shape (rectangle, circle, polygon) used to draw filled areas.
An annotation is text added to a chart to label or explain a point, trend, or region.
In Matplotlib, arrowprops are settings that control how an arrow looks in an annotation (style, width, color, etc.).
A marker is a point symbol used in plots (shape, size, color) to represent data points.
Ticks are the small marks on an axis that show the scale positions.
Tick labels are the text labels shown next to axis ticks (e.g., dates or numbers).
In plotting, layout refers to the arrangement of chart elements (titles, axes, margins, legends, spacing).
A grid is a set of reference lines or layout structure used to align elements and improve readability in charts.
A legend explains what colors, symbols, or lines represent in a chart.
Exploratory data analysis (EDA) is the process of exploring data to find patterns, anomalies, and questions to investigate.
Explanatory data analysis focuses on communicating known insights clearly to an audience.
Clutter is unnecessary visual noise in a chart (extra labels, gridlines, colors) that makes it harder to read.
The proximity principle says items placed close together are perceived as related; useful for grouping in charts/dashboards.
In data visualization, guiding attention means designing the chart so viewers notice the most important information first.
Contrast is the difference between visual elements (color, size, brightness) used to improve readability and emphasis.
Use colors sparingly: apply color only where it adds meaning, so highlights stand out and the chart stays readable.
Data storytelling combines data, visuals, and narrative to explain insights and drive decisions.
A grid is a set of reference lines or layout structure used to align elements and improve readability in charts.
An axis (singular) is one dimension of a plot (x-axis or y-axis) with a scale and ticks.
An insight is a meaningful takeaway from data that helps answer a question or guide a decision.
Context is the background information (time, units, comparisons, definitions) that makes a visualization understandable.
A call to action is the clear next step you want the viewer to take after seeing a chart or dashboard.
An annotation is text added to a chart to label or explain a point, trend, or region.
Key Performance Indicator (KPI): a measurable metric used to track progress toward a goal.
A story arc is the narrative structure of a data story: setup → tension/question → insight → takeaway/action.
Data literacy is the ability to read, understand, question, and communicate with data.
Dashboard fatigue is when users stop engaging because dashboards are overloaded, repetitive, or hard to interpret.
A choropleth map colors geographic areas based on a value (e.g., unemployment by region).
In Plotly, fig.update_layout updates a figure’s layout settings (titles, margins, legend, axes, etc.).
A radar chart plots multiple variables on axes radiating from a center to compare profiles across categories.
A spider chart is another name for a radar chart.
Mapbox is a mapping platform often used as a basemap/provider for interactive maps in tools like Plotly.
GeoJSON is a JSON format for geographic features (points, lines, polygons) and their properties.
A bubble chart is a scatter plot where marker size represents a third value (in addition to x and y).
A pie chart shows parts of a whole as slices; it’s best for a few categories and rough comparisons.
In Plotly, hovertemplate controls the text shown when you hover over a point.
In Plotly, a trace is one set of plotted data (e.g., one line, one bar series) within a figure.
on_action is a callback/event handler triggered when a user performs an action (e.g., clicking a button).
on_change is a callback/event handler triggered when an input value changes.
State is stored information that represents the current condition of an app (e.g., selected filters, current page).
Key Performance Indicator (KPI): a measurable metric used to track progress toward a goal.
